choices.B: each user in Microsoft 365 admin center
choices.A: each instance of Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) associated to the tenant

discussion.content: D is correct. If you go to Settings, Administration, System Settings, General Tab and scroll nearly to the bottom, you'll see "Set inactivity timeout". You can turn it on or off, and if on, configure the duration and warning times. This applies only to the instance/org.

comments.content: @omarrana: wow, I'm impressed, this what you say here is soo important to me and extremely helpful! :P

questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service system administrator for a Sandbox and a Production instance.
A user forgets to sign out from a shared device connected to a Production instance. A second user makes changes to records using the credentials of the first user.
You need to implement user session timeouts to prevent this type of issue from recurring.
Where should you configure this feature?

discussion.content: Definitely C. Prefix is set in the publisher profile, and there's no such thing as a package type or release date as it applies to a solution.

Checking but this says change the prefix of the Publisher - so in this questions example would that not be more appropriate? 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customerengagement/on-premises/customize/change-solution-publisher-prefix

questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service developer.
You need to configure a new solution.
What should you configure in the new solution?

You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service system administrator.
Users report that a subgrid from the Onsite Goals custom entity takes a very long time to load on the Account records page.
You need to improve the query load time and optimize the Onsite Goals entity.
Which action should you perform?

discussion.content:
I have seen several questions talking about Data Performance Logs. I believe the exams are focused on latest versions of Dynamics. This feature as per best of my knowledge, has been removed now. The Settings->Administration doesn't offer this option.

Considering this, the only option available is to check Diagnostic Tool. Also, need to understand from someone who has already attempted the exam if such questions are still in exam as it doesn't make any sense to question about already removed functionality

comments.content: I agree, would also say that the Diagnostic Tool is the right option.

Looks closest to right answer. "Data Perform view" is odd wording, as it's called "Data Performance" or "Data Performance Logs". But this is the most logical answer. D might apply if the system was generally sluggish, but not for one specific scenario such as noted. A and C make no sense.

choices.C: In System Jobs, resume paused system jobs.
choices.B: In the Data Perform view, use the Optimize functions.
choices.A: In an Internet browser, in the browser options, set the option to retain browser history.
choices.D: In the Dynamics 365 Diagnostic tool, run the diagnostic test.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service system administrator. You use the Data Performance tool. There are 14 items in the All Data Performance Logs view. Some log items detail positive operational impact percentages while others detail negative operational percentages.
Users report that the system is less responsive than in the past.
You need to improve system performance.
Solution: Select optimize for log items to remove Microsoft SQL Server indexes which may not be used and that slow performance.
Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content: Option B. "NO" is the correct answer
Data Performance tool doesn't exist any more, so I don't expect this question in the exam. Replaced by Azure SQL optimizations (not sure)

comments.content: sadly that doesnt mean they won't still ask it.. :(
Not everyone can be master like you

As per discussion on a related question from this group, the correct course of action is to remove the optimizations that have degraded performance (the ones showing a positive operational effect). Thus, "No" is the correct response to this question.

discussion.content: this should be a yes, correct??

questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service system administrator. You set up server-side synchronization. You plan to deploy the Dynamics 365 App for
Outlook after users have received training.
Users do not have administrator rights.
You need to identify which method you would use to deploy Dynamics 365 App for the trained users.
Which method will accomplish this goal?

choices.D: Push the App for Outlook to only select users from Dynamics 365 Settings area.
choices.B: Have users install themselves directly from the Dynamics 365 Settings area.
choices.E: Push the App for Outlook manually or automatically to all eligible users from Dynamics 365 Settings area.
choices.C: Have users install themselves from the personal Settings area.
choices.A: Push the App for Outlook to all eligible users from the Dynamics 365 administration center.

discussion.content:
D is Correct. Key is that selected users should get access. 
A - incorrect because app cannot be pushed from admin center
B - incorrect because we need to think from the action perspective of admin, App is not yet deployed + selected users who finish the training should get the access, none other
C - incorrect because nothing can be INSTALLED from personal settings area.
E - incorrect as it does not allow selecting users 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-engagement/outlook-app/v8/deploy-dynamics-365-app-for-outlook#main

comments.content: Ah I get it.. I actually thought it was E as well. BUT you need to only roll out to SELECT few users who have received training. So, it shouldn't automatically rolled out (not E), it shouldn't even be manually rolled out to elligible users (so not A). The answer is D! Because you need to select the TRAINED users one by one and push only for them.

Again this is an "it depends" and vague question. It says you've set up Server Side Sync already. The question is: did you just set up the server profile and default sync settings for new users, OR did you also ensure everyone is set to server side sync and test & enable their mailboxes already. If the former, then E is correct, and you can just Test & Enable the users that receive training, and they would get App for Outlook at that time automatically. However, I think the implication is that you've done the full set up already including enabling user mailboxes, in which case D is correct. I think. I wish questions could not be this ambiguous!

discussion.content:
It's another strange question. It can be D and E as well.
At https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/outlook-app/v8/deploy-dynamics-365-app-for-outlook
it says: 4 - Do one of the following:
 ☺To push the app to all eligible users, click Add App for All Eligible Users.
 ☺To push the app to certain users, select those users in the list, and then click Add App to Outlook.

 If you think that only users that received the training must have the app and NOT ALL USERS RECEIVED the training, so its D, because you have to select users by yourself.
if your understood is that all eligible users received the training an then all of them needs the access to the app so E is the right answer
So, you have to think what does MS wanted to say by "after users have received training"

To push the app to all eligible users, click Add App for All Eligible Users.
To push the app to certain users, select those users in the list, and then click Add App to 
Outlook.
So correct answer is E

Correct Answer is E . Push the App for Outlook manually or automatically to all eligible users from Dynamics 365 Settings. 
area.

D is the correct inswer because if we wany To push the app to certain users, select those users in the list, and then click Add App to Outlook.
Refer To : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/outlook-app/v8/deploy-dynamics-365-app-for-outlook#main

comments.content: As Suchi noted below, that's not where you install from. You install by going to the cog (which is Personal OPTIONS not Personal Settings) and selecting Apps for Dynamics 365 I'm 99% sure C is not correct.

discussion.content: I think that the correct answer is C. Have users install themselves from the personal Settings area. The key here is the "personal Settings area".

comments.content: B actually is a possibility as well, in the real world. You could just tell each user at the end of their training to go to the cog and click Apps for Dynamics 365 to get it. But the way the question is worded, it sounds like they want the administrator to take care of the installation instead, rather than coaching the users through the process. In that case, the correct answer is either D or E (see my reply to Feminho below for more details). I'm pretty sure they are looking for D in this question. But could be wrong.

discussion.content: Is D correct? What about B?
